data.abstract: This chapter considers the clinical virology laboratory and reviews the use of virus genome detection for clinical diagnosis, which has increased dramatically. In general, virus genome detection is more rapid and sensitive than cell-culture and can be used before a detectable antibody response has developed. The chapter traces the discovery of potent antivirals for hepatitis C, hepatitis B, HIV, and influenza, wherein there is a huge demand for the diagnostic laboratory to monitor levels of virus in the appropriate clinical sample of the patient using rapid molecular tests. These tests can also give the first indication of drug-resistant virus mutants, which could compromise antiviral therapy. The chapter covers the collection and transport of clinical specimens to the laboratory, different rapid diagnostic methods, the isolation of viruses in cell cultures, and the detection of antiviral antibodies.
title: The clinical virology laboratory
